ai-iti99:1.1_0: This was said by the Buddha, the Perfected One: that is what I heard.
ai-iti99:2.1_0: “Mendicants, I describe a brahmin who is master of the three Vedic knowledges in terms of the teaching, not by mere oral recitation.
ai-iti99:3.1_0: For how can I describe a brahmin who is master of the three Vedic knowledges in terms of the teaching, not by mere oral recitation?
ai-iti99:3.2_0: It’s when a mendicant recollects many kinds of past lives. That is:
ai-iti99:3.2_1: ʻThere I had such a name, such a family, such appearance, such food, such experience of happiness and suffering, and such a life-span.
ai-iti99:3.2_2: passing away from there I arose in another state of existence,
ai-iti99:3.2_3: and there I had such a name, such a family, such appearance, such food, such experience of happiness and suffering, and such a life-span.
ai-iti99:3.2_4: When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else.
ai-iti99:3.2_5: They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
ai-iti99:3.3_0: This is the first knowledge that arose.
ai-iti99:4.1_0: Furthermore, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, a mendicant sees sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds:
ai-iti99:4.1_1: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.
ai-iti99:4.1_2: They spoke ill of the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view.
ai-iti99:4.1_3: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
ai-iti99:4.1_4: at the breaking up of the body after death, have been reborn in a good destination, a heaven world.’
ai-iti99:4.1_5: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never spoke ill of the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
ai-iti99:4.2_0: This is the second knowledge that arose.
ai-iti99:5.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
ai-iti99:5.2_0: This is the third knowledge that arose.
ai-iti99:5.3_0: That’s how I describe a brahmin who is master of the three Vedic knowledges in terms of the teaching, not by mere oral recitation.”
ai-iti99:5.4_0: That is what the Buddha said.
ai-iti99:6.2_0: seeing heaven and places of loss,
ai-iti99:6.3_0: and have attained the end of rebirth;
ai-iti99:7.2_0: that the brahmin is a master of the three knowledges.
ai-iti99:7.3_0: I call a master of the three knowledges.
ai-iti99:8.1_0: This too was spoken by the Blessed One: that is what I heard.
ai-iti99:9.2_0: With the complete ending of the fire,
ai-iti99:9.4_0: giving a gift to those Dhamma.
ai-iti99:9.5_0: The Book of the Threes is finished.
